constellations_primary.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_primary.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.title_for_label: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.description:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague

results.title: Dressing Dad
results.creator_credit: Sofya Gollan, Isabel Perez and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A short student film in which the filmmaker explores how the relationship with her father was transformed by the knowledge of his being a cross-dresser. Featuring interviews with her father and his transvestite friends, this work dispels many of the common preconceptions about cross-dressing and transvestitism while also being an engaging study of how families cope with aspects of individual difference and gender exploration.

results.title: Fire of the land (A) [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: This beautifully written, produced and directed documentary by AFTRS student Valerie Bichard encapsulates the emotions and determination of a group of Aboriginal Australians seeking peace and justice in their campaign for Sovereign Rights. Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.

results.title: Tears
results.brief_description: The lone desert highway leads from an Aboriginal settlement to a bus shelter which offers both the promise of opportunity and the danger of isolation. For the young teenage girl, the bus out of the desert means hope for legitimacy, freedom and an escape from the scars of a ruthless colonisation. For the boy, the escape might mean leaving behind the only family, community and safety he has ever known. Ivan Sen’s remarkable short film, utilising sparse dialogue and a harshly eloquent mise-en-scene, forces an audience to comprehend the terrible, seemingly futile optimism of will that is required of its young protagonists in imaging a future.

results.title: Acquiring a taste for Raffaella
results.creator_credit: Sandra Lepore, Fotini Manikakis and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The onset of menstruation leads to a curious mix of events when Raffaella shares the news with her traditional Italian Aunt. Together they make some special Italian love biscuits, “biscotti di amore”, with a secret ingredient intimately linked with Raffaella’s menarche. When the object of her affections tastes the love biscuits, surprisingly, he asks for the recipe.

results.title: In the name of the crow
results.creator_credit: Marion Benjamin, Mark Bin Bakar, Peter Kordyl, Robert Bropho, Heather Williams and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description: Most tourists who visit Rottnest Island are unaware of its history. Established as a prison for Aboriginal men around 1840, it was intended as a place for “rehabilitation”. However, accounts of floggings, chainings and hangings flourished on the mainland despite official enquiries and commissions suggesting everything was in order. In this documentary, Robert Bropho takes us to the island and traces the hardship and the suffering of his ancestors that has been omitted from white man’s history.
